 ...
 

 
 You are reading an abridged version of the Constitution. That is NOT the original verison of the 2nd Amendment to the Constitution.
 
 Here it is, WITH all Capitalization AND Punctuation included:
 
 "A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed."
 
 The subject and purpose of the entire 2nd Amendment is made entirely clear at the very begining of the sentence. That subject and purpose of the 
 2nd Amendment pertains to the remainder of the entire sentence. The sentence can't be chopped apart and part of it taken out of the context of a militia.
 
 The right to keep and bear arms can not be separated from the purpose of that specified Right, which is for a militia. 
 
 Had the Founding Fathers wanted to just talk about gun ownership for ANY, purpose, they would have done so, by expanding the end of the sentence to read:
 
 "A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, for any legitimate purpose, shall not be infringed."
 
 Another way they could have done so, would have been to break apart the 2nd Amendment into 2 parts. 
 
 "A well regulated Militia, is necessary for the security of a free State."
 
 "The right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed."
 
 The Founding Fathers did not write the 2nd Amendment in either of those ways. 
 
 We can not infer ANY purpose or reason for the 2nd Amendment, other than what is clearly stated as a purpose for a militia: 
 1) to maintain a Free State, and 
 2) ensure that the right to keep and bear arms for a militia is not infringed.
